title: The Evolutionary Dynamics of Independent Learning Agents in Population Games
abstract:
Abstract
Understanding the evolutionary dynamics of reinforcement learning under multi-agent settings has long remained an open problem.
While previous works primarily focus on 222-player games, we consider population games, which model the strategic interactions of a large population comprising small and anonymous agents.
This paper presents a formal relation between stochastic processes and the dynamics of independent learning agents who reason based on the reward signals.
Using a master equation approach, we provide a novel unified framework for characterising population dynamics via a single partial differential equation (Theorem 1).
Through a case study involving Cross learning agents, we illustrate that Theorem 1 allows us to identify qualitatively different evolutionary dynamics, to analyse steady states, and to gain insights into the expected behaviour of a population.
In addition, we present extensive experimental results validating that Theorem 1 holds for a variety of learning methods and population games.
